Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Improving Livingness by Detailed Kinetic Studies into ATRP
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Krzysztof Matyjaszewski of Carnegie-Mellon University is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry for an International Collaboration in Chemistry (ICC) grant to conduct detailed exploration of medium effects (including temperature, pressure, and various solvents) on the livingness in atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) and to gain a better mechanistic understanding of the polymerization process. This work includes an international collaboration with Professor Michael Buback of the University of Goettingen (Germany). Professor Buback's work is supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft German Research Foundation (DFG) of Germany. Prof. Matyjaszewski and Prof. Buback aim to determine kinetic information of the ATRP process using pulsed-laser-induced polymerization followed by highly time-resolved EPR to detect radical species and high-pressure online VIS-NIR-IR spectroscopy to monitor monomer concentration. The experimental work will be accompanied by modeling. The U.S. graduate students will spend three months each year in Germany to learn high-pressure experiments with quantitative spectroscopic techniques.

This research will lead to fundamental knowledge important for improving polymerization processes to better control complex architecture and properties of polymers. It will impact basic fundamental science and applied technologies. In addition, this international collaboration provides unique research environments for training students and postdoctoral researchers and preparing them for careers in academia or polymer industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES  REPORT FOR AWARD # 1026060

Carnegie Mellon University 

International Collaboration in Chemistry: Improving Livingness by Detailed Kinetic Studies into ATRP

Project Outcome:

 Matyjaszewski’s group developed several simple and versatile polymerization techniques, based on atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP), in the presence of ppm amounts of copper catalyst and various reducing agents. They include organic (sugars, vitamin C, amines) and inorganic compounds  (zerovalent metals, sulfites) as well as physical sources such as electrical current or light (as shown in the top two images). Medium effects, solvents, temperature and pressure  were studied to further enhance  control in ATRP. Pressure effects, studied in collaboration with Prof. Buback’s group, have tremendous influence on ATRP and enhance livingness. Side reactions  with very active  ATRP catalysts were identified and conditions were  developed to minimize their contributions and enhance/improve livingness, accomplishing the main goals of the project.

 

Impact & Benefits:

Cu-based catalysts for ATRP  can be now used at ppm level to reduce cost,
benefit environment and also  enhance control, by diminishing contributions of side reactions. This research project provided  guidelines how much catalyst/ligand  is required for a certain targeting degree of polymerization and designed polymer dispersity.  ATRP is used industrially in US, Japan and Europe and Carnegie Mellon signed  already 15 commercial licenses. We formed two industrial Consortia to facilitate transfer and dissemination of generated knowledge to industry via Consortium program and also to academia by timely publications and a website visited over 50,000 times annually.

 

Background & Explanation:

Atom transfer radical polymerization is the most commonly used controlled radical polymerization system with >1000 papers published annually. Efforts in Matyjaszewski’s group  are focused on kinetic and mechanistic  studies in order to develop more efficient catalytic systems and  improve livingness of ATRP. Further efforts are focused on more environmentally benign processes, including iron-based systems  and exploring medium effects, especially pressure, in collaboration with Professor Buback’s group at University of Goettingen. Graduate students from both groups spent several months in the collaborator’s laboratory. We organized Controlled Radical Polymerization Symposium at ACS in Denver and published two volumes proceedings.  We also co-edited 10-volume (270 Chapters, 7550 pages) “Polymer Science: A Comprehensive Reference”  published
by Elsevier in 2012 (as shown at bottom three images).

 


Last Modified: 09/10/2013
Modified by: Krzysztof Matyjaszewski
